50. A Meleager, carried in death,
was also greatly admired by the Romans.
There one sees depicted how each bearer,
is also a mourner, with a sorrowful heart;
and the strength of the labor is well suggested
and in that dead Corpse above all
the art is not the lesser or insignificant; it seemed
fully powerless and dead, in trunk, limbs and fingers.

51. I have in my memory a Modern piece,
on the Capitoline Hill, with signed of such grace
in emotions, to the glory of the Painter:
and it is the history of the combat
of the three Horatii and the Curiatii,
there one saw Tullus the Roman King, alas,
sitting with his Lords, justly sad
that his last Man had to fight against three.
right-middleThis was an old-fashioned Painting in which Sorrow, Joy, and Death were very naturally depicted.

52. And it seemed that he mourned his two Brothers,
his Champions, lying there defeated.
It seemed too that the Painter knew the correct manner
of depicting, with wonderful art, the dying actions of these Knights.
Also it seemed that the hearts of Mettus and the Alba Longans
swam joyfully in a sea of gladness
Since their warriors (as it appeared) carried the day.

53. This was depicted in such a distinctive
calm manner that many were amazed.
Also, it is not at all despised
for being so different from our own time.
For it is perhaps a century old.
The color and handling are exceptional;
one sees very few like it
in painting the essence of Emotions.
right-middleThis piece now (I believe) belongs to Emperor Rudolp.

54. From the excellent and faultless Brueghel
there is yet in a Massacre of the Innocents
a deathly pale Mother, overwhelmed in a swoon,
yes, a wretched family beseeching a Herald
to spare a child’s life, in whom
can be espied compassion well enough,
but with pained feeling he displays the King’s proclamation
that mercy must be shown toward none.

55. Thus, learning of surely endless examples,
Ancient and Modern,
let your heart be aflame with burning desire
for these Emotions as proper Teachers,
or the Soul, which Art keeps within itself
like the kernel of a nut,
right-middleDepicting the emotions, the Soul of Art.
